articles.headline: Despite Trump’s Nudging, Schools Are Likely to Stay Shut for Months
articles.snippet: Most districts have no plans to end online lessons soon, and reopening will bring significant changes, educators say.
articles.abstract: Most districts have no plans to end online lessons soon, and reopening will bring significant changes, educators say.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — With students languishing, the economy stagnating and working parents straining to turn their kitchen tables into classrooms, the nation’s public schools have been working to bring children back to their desks, lockers and study halls.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler, Erica L. Green and Dana Goldstein

articles.headline: Trump Declares Meat Supply ‘Critical,’ Aiming to Reopen Plants
articles.snippet: The executive order is meant to prevent shortages of pork, chicken and other products. But unions fear it will endanger workers in the plants, which have become coronavirus hot spots.
articles.abstract: The executive order is meant to prevent shortages of pork, chicken and other products. But unions fear it will endanger workers in the plants, which have become coronavirus hot spots.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday declared meat processing plants “critical infrastructure,” in an effort to ensure that facilities around the country remained open as the government tried to prevent looming shortages of pork, chicken and other products as a result of the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Biggest Mall Operator in U.S. Plans to Reopen 49 of Them
articles.snippet: In a memo, Simon Property Group laid out how it planned to open the properties in 10 states between Friday and Monday.
articles.abstract: In a memo, Simon Property Group laid out how it planned to open the properties in 10 states between Friday and Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Simon Property Group, the biggest operator of malls in the United States, has come up with a game plan for reopening 49 shopping centers across 10 states starting on Friday.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Treasury Vows to Recoup Virus Relief Aid Claimed by Big Companies
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, said the administration would audit any company that received more than $2 million.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin, said the administration would audit any company that received more than $2 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Los Angeles Lakers are not what most people think of as a small business. Yet the basketball franchise is the latest example of a large company that managed to qualify for small-business loans from a hastily devised government program intended to help barbershops, restaurants, dry cleaners and other mom-and-pop shops.

articles.headline: ‘Will You Help Save My Brother?’: The Scramble to Find Covid-19 Plasma Donors
articles.snippet: A doctor stricken with Covid-19 was running out of options. His family mounted a search for a donor whose plasma might help.
articles.abstract: A doctor stricken with Covid-19 was running out of options. His family mounted a search for a donor whose plasma might help.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The doctor was dying.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and Amy Harmon

articles.headline: Bridge Was Their Passion. Then People Started to Die.
articles.snippet: A bridge club was a social draw for scores of older Coloradans. Now, with four members dead from the virus, its future is unclear.
articles.abstract: A bridge club was a social draw for scores of older Coloradans. Now, with four members dead from the virus, its future is unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — It had already been a grim day. The governor of Colorado had just announced the state’s first coronavirus death, an 83-year-old woman, when public health investigators discovered where she had spent some of her final days: a bridge club.

articles.headline: The Victoria’s Secret Contract That Anticipated a Pandemic
articles.snippet: A buyout firm is trying to back out of its deal for Victoria’s Secret, citing the coronavirus. The contract’s wording will make that tricky.
articles.abstract: A buyout firm is trying to back out of its deal for Victoria’s Secret, citing the coronavirus. The contract’s wording will make that tricky.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s no wonder the buyout firm Sycamore Partners is trying to back out of its $525 million deal to buy a majority of Victoria’s Secret from struggling L Brands.

articles.headline: Worst Economy in a Decade. What’s Next? ‘Worst in Our Lifetime.’
articles.snippet: U.S. gross domestic product declined in the first quarter, dragged down by the pandemic’s grip in March. Don’t even ask about this quarter.
articles.abstract: U.S. gross domestic product declined in the first quarter, dragged down by the pandemic’s grip in March. Don’t even ask about this quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic officially snapped the United States’ economic growth streak in the first three months of the year. The question now is how deep the damage will get — and how long the country will take to recover.
